NORMAL IMMUNOGLOBULIN

  • Indications and doses
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Prescribing and dispensing
  • Handling and storage
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

To control outbreaks of hepatitis A,

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    500 mg.

Rubella in pregnancy, prevention of clinical attack,

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults females of childbearing potential
    750 mg.

Antibody deficiency syndromes,

By subcutaneous infusion

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Contra indications

  • Patients with selective IgA deficiency who have known antibody against IgA

Known side effects

General side effects

rare: Acute renal failure, anaphylaxis, aseptic meningitis, cutaneous skin reactions, hypotension,

notKnown: Arthralgia, chills, diarrhoea, dizziness, fever, headache, low back pain, muscle spasms, myalgia, nausea,

Specific side effects

notKnown: abdominal distension, abdominal pain, blood pressure fluctuations, deep vein thrombosis, haemolytic anaemia, injection site reactions, myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, stroke, thromboembolic events,

Adverse reactions are more likely to occur in patients receiving normal immunoglobulin for the first time, or following a prolonged period between treatments, or when a different brand of normal immunoglobulin is administered.

Directions for administration

Preparations for subcutaneous use

May be administered by intramuscular injection if subcutaneous route not possible; intramuscular route not for patients with thrombocytopenia or other bleeding disorders.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Agammaglobulinaemia with or without IgA deficiency
  • hypogammaglobulinaemia with or without IgA deficiency
  • interference with live virus vaccines
  • With intravenous use: ensure adequate hydration
  • With intravenous use: obesity
  • With intravenous use: renal insufficiency
  • With intravenous use: risk factors for arterial thromboembolic events
  • With intravenous use: risk factors for venous thromboembolic events
  • With intravenous use: thrombophilic disorders

  • Normal immunoglobulin may interfere with the immune response to live virus vaccines which should therefore only be given at least 3 weeks before or 3 months after an injection of normal immunoglobulin (this does not apply to yellow fever vaccine since normal immunoglobulin does not contain antibody to this virus).

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor for acute renal failure; consider discontinuation if renal function deteriorates. Intravenous preparations with added sucrose have been associated with cases of renal dysfunction and acute renal failure.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Antibody titres can vary widely between normal immunoglobulin preparations from different manufacturers—formulations are not interchangeable; patients should be maintained on the same formulation throughout long-term treatment to avoid adverse effects.

With intramuscular use

Available from the Centre for Infections and other regional Public Health England offices (for contacts and control of outbreaks only).

Advice regarding handling and storage

Care must be taken to store all immunological products under the conditions recommended in the product literature, otherwise the preparation may become ineffective. Refrigerated storage is usually necessary; many immunoglobulins need to be stored at 2–8°C and not allowed to freeze. Immunoglobulins should be protected from light. Opened multidose vials must be used within the period recommended in the product literature.

Prepared medicinal forms of NORMAL IMMUNOGLOBULIN

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for injection
Powder and solvent for solution for injection
Solution for infusion
